author: {'steamid': '76561198019125511', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 71, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 71, 'playtime_at_review': 71, 'last_played': 1712057062}
review:
[h1]古典的 横スクACT を最大限リスペクトしたゲェム[/h1]
本作品は「悪魔城ドラキュラ」の影響を大きく受けた、古典的横スクロールアクションをリスペクトした作品である。
近接武器の鞭と遠距離武器の銃を切り替えながら敵をシバき倒して進むオーソドックスなアクションゲームだ。

このゲームの評価の分かれ目は、以下のポイント。
[h2]昔ながらのアクションゲームの要素を良しとするか悪しとするか[/h2]
である。
[b]
・初見殺し、穴落としは結構ある
・落下判定が厳しい、進行方向と逆にスクロールしない
・武器切り替えにクールダウンがあるなど多少の不便さはある
・通常攻撃も予備動作（振りかぶり）が長い
[/b]

この「古典的横スクACT」にありがちな要素を受け入れるか嫌うかで評価が大きく分かれるだろう。
しかし現在ではそうした「理不尽さ」や「操作性の悪さ」とも言える要素も踏襲しつつである。
[b]
・移動は軽快で素早く動ける
・ジャンプ中も空中制動が効き自由に動ける＋ジャンプの高さ調節も可能
・鞭攻撃も判定広め＋持続長い＋振りかぶりも大きい上方向判定あり
・初見殺しはあるものの、それだけでなくキッチリ「アクション」を要求するデザイン
・初見殺しは多いものの１ＵＰアイテムが多く出る
・素晴らしいドット、グラフィック
[/b]

などなどの要素があり。
[h2]とても３００円で買えるゲームとは思えないゲームの出来だ。[/h2]
正直「１０００円超えでこれよりよっぽど出来の悪いゲーム」など山程あると言った印象。

私のゲームの腕前は悪魔城ドラキュラ１周目ならNormalノーコン安定程度の腕前だが、クリアまで１時間弱ちょっとで常に楽しく遊べた。
難易度選択もある様子なのでより上の難易度に挑むのも良いし、カジュアルに遊んでも良いし何ならノーミスチャレンジなども面白そうだなと思う。


このゲームは古典的横スクACTの…
[h2]覚えていけば攻略が加速する、その上でアクションするのがより楽しくなる[/h2]
という、「自分を常に褒めてくれる」つまり課題を超えていく楽しさという体験をちゃんと与えてくれるので、アクションゲーマーとしてはこれは楽しいゲームだったと感じた。

昔ACTに見られる初見殺しや穴落とし等の要素や多少の操作性の悪さは「あえて用意したのもの」であり、その他の要素はしっかりと現代風に直されている部分が大きいので、これらは「そこを踏まえて攻略を考えてくれよ」という思想に見受けられた。

これは評価が大きく分かれる所ではあるが、そうした古典的横スクＡＣＴが好きな人間からすれば。
[h2]古典的横スクＡＣＴが好きなら間違いなく気に入るとオススメできる[/h2]
作品だ。


欠点は、間違いなく「昔ACT」なのでどうしても「敷居が高い」ところだろうか。
ゲームの勘が働くのであれば「あ～はいはいこういうヤツね」とすぐ攻略を見いだせるだろうが、そうでなければかなり沼らされるので体験が悪くなるかもしれない。

そういう意味で「ゲームの腕前に自信の無い方」にはより勧めにくい作品かもしれない事も書き留めておく。


そんな所で、購入の参考になれば幸いである。
自分はとても楽しかった。

review: A fun throwback to some of the best 2D Platformers of the 80s, Crypt Stalker takes after both Castlevania's style and level design while the gameplay physics are more similar to that of Vice: Project Doom. While the main "Console game" isn't that long, the bevy of extra side modes including the Handheld Stages, Boss Rush, and extra Challenges will certainly add quite a bit of replay value for this low price. The only thing that annoyed me was that several bosses relied on really fast instant death moves which felt a little cheap, especially during the boss rush. Overall though, this game is very enjoyable, and the graphics and soundtrack deserve special kudos for being authentic and awesome.

author: {'steamid': '76561198094203138', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 386, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 217, 'last_played': 1671904722}
review:
If you like Bloodstained's retro spin off Curse of The Moon series, this game should be right up your alley.

So Crypt Stalker is a retro NES inspired game, that fairly authentically captures the old game feel and aesthetic and not feel like it's more of an after thought, some real effort went into this game.

The game is divvied up into two separate versions, a console mode which is the more complete version with 9 whole levels, and a short handheld mode with it's own 4 distinctive levels. Gladys our main character is sort of a female Belmont and Indiana Jones hybrid since she wields a unique whip that can be upgraded into a flame whip, and can actually swing on specific objects, and has a gun that you can find actual different weapon types for, and actually collect ammo in the form of bullets and large shells.

Graphically the console mode is the best looking as it captures a classic retro NES look where as I feel most other "retro themed" games kind of fail, since there's a real effort here, the player sprites, enemies and backgrounds are clear and distinctive with a unique set of enemies. Not to mention the bosses. While handheld mode is very much old game boy styled, complete with a Game Boy-ish border that's akin to certain old Game Boy emulators.

Gameplay wise it's very speedy and responsive, although sometimes it feels a little extra slick in spots but you can get used to it. And Gladys is in basically a full on sprint, and only goes into a more typical Belmont strut in handheld mode. And some mechanics and even certain boss encounters are going to make you think of other games besides just Castlevania, there's a twinge of Snake's Revenge in one level mixed with Sonic, another sorta Sonic-ish mechanic, even a Sonic-ish boss, as well as a boss that's very much Mega Man in nature. The different bullet types you can get are a standard bullet, a lazer, a gas bullet, and a high explosive round, which is essentially the best ammo type, dishes out two points of damage to most health bars.

Sound design is pretty solid, no grating sound effects and a lot of them sound appropriate and console correct. For more astute NES gamers, there are some actual familiar sound effects but they play very rarely. And the music is phenomenal. Loads of great tracks, sounding fittingly retro while using some of the better NES sound card music from the NES library compared to some others which I'm glad it didn't go for.

The difficulty is fairly well done. It starts out somewhat easy but does kind of drastically spike part way through the game but it never feels utterly unfair, even the challenges weren't hair pullingly frustrating which I was real thankful for, they were tough but not impossible, some were surprisingly easier than others. It can be beaten entirely within around 3 or so hours depending on how well you do. Not a bad length for a game of this type and price. So I do highly recommend for classic gaming fans or those wanting a not so insanely difficult retro themed game since that's another problem I've noted with some retro games, taking the old difficulty to an insane level. This is tough but fair with only one boss you're bound to die on a good few times, both in main game and in the boss rush.

If you want a good quality retro adventure, this is a good one.

review:
First, as you've probably gleaned, this game is Castlevania (or Castlevania: the Adventure, depending on the mode), so if you are a fan of the original Castlevania games, you'll like this as well.

I have seen few games so committed to source authenticity. Both the console and handheld levels are designed to simulate the capabilities and limitations of those consoles, for good or ill. This does mean that the game is very challenging, though I didn't find Crypt Stalker to be as punitive as some games of the era. It is difficult but but not unfair.

Beyond that...what can I say that I haven't already said about? It's an extension of Castlevania, and I'm sure that you know if that's the game for you. It's only three dollars, so why not give it a shot?

review:
It looks and sounds really good, but the gameplay is more important. It's well imitates the retro style, but the key word is "imitate". «Crypt Stalker» is much easier than the usual NES games, but only until the dev wants to create a moment where you'll be stuck for the next 10 min. There are also enough bugs: char stuck in platforms, broken vertical scrolling, problems with menu buttons, but for one I'm even grateful: infinity lives bug. The dev promised to fix it, but it's still here. If not it, I wouldn't try to finish the last levels hard sections (the final boss is an insane test of luck / reaction).
➤ P.S. This isn't the first retro platformer project from this dev. If the idea was to create "the old era spirit" games, why not take the best parts, like: smoother controls, better visual separation of fore/backgrounds, lack of the unnecessary frustration from the unfirly hard "stretch the game" moments? I really didn't want to leave a negative review for this, but a year has passed since the release.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017648023', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 717, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 717, 'last_played': 1623420570}
review:
Crypt Stalker é um pequeno plataforma retrô carregado de nostalgia da era dos 8-bits e com uma enorme reverência aos período clássico de Castlevania. E o jogo se esforça bastante para recriar a atmosfera dos primeiros plataformas dos consoles (e portáteis também com as fases extras), chegando ao ponto de incluir as infames "piscadas" quando a personagem é atingida.

Dos visuais até a trilha sonora, passando até pela própria "narrativa" do jogo que se limita a te dar um contexto pra história, tudo nesse jogo tenta transpirar aos anos 80/90 da história dos plataforma. Mas se tem algo daquela época que o jogo faz a escolha acertada de não recriar são os controles e animações travadas cheios de input lag e a dificuldade que por vezes te fazia querer testar a resistência da manete no chão.

Não que Crypt Stalker seja um jogo fácil. A dificuldade é na maior parte do tempo é bem dosada, exceto em alguns momentos em que as fases se estendem por demais, e o jogo traz bons chefões. Não demandam muita habilidade para se derrotar, mas te mantém sempre engajado na luta. Se há uma critica a fazer é que o jogo se mantém muito na sua zona de conforto, uma repetição de level design que vai ficando cada vez mais aparente e uns bugs aqui e acolá. Porém considerando a sua proposta de recriar o "feel" daqueles tempos, é perdoável!

Enfim, Crypt Stalker é um jogo de plataforma competente que resgata o sentimento de épocas mais simples e irá agradar jogadores que buscam uma experiência nostálgica sem muito compromisso.

author: {'steamid': '76561198360472714', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 396, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 396, 'last_played': 1632422605}
review:
A Sinclair Strange é uma produtora fãs dos jogos 8bits da Nintendo. Em Crypt Stalker, eles (ou ele, já que é apenas um desenvolvedor) criaram uma grande homenagem ao saudoso tempo dos Castlevanias do Nintendinho, mas numa ambientação egípcia.

Assim como no jogo Alien Splatter Redux, Crypt Stalker parece ser mesmo um jogo da época (gráficos, trilha e efeitos sonoros, dificuldade absurda) e não me espantaria se fosse lançado em cartucho compatível com o videogame. O jogo lembra demais o Castlevania, o que pode ser considerado como uma grande homenagem ou uma gigantesca cópia (cabe cada um decidir), mas no meu caso achei positivo e voltei aos anos 80 jogando no meu velho Dynavision.

O único porém são alguns bugs que atrapalham bastante. Na segunda fase, você pode ficar preso em alguns locais que não dão para sair (só morrendo ou resetando), alguns inimigos caem em buracos e deixam de oferecer perigo ou as caveiras que deixam de "cuspir" e facilitam a sua jornada. Contudo, o que achei mais estranho, foi numa das últimas vezes que joguei: passei por várias fases e fui acumulando uma quantidade absurda de vidas, o que me permitiu ir até o penúltimo estágio do game. Até agora não sei se isso é da mecânica do Crypt Stalker ou foi erro, mas agradeço. ;)

Resumindo: É fã de Castlevania dos anos 80? Jogue sem medo.

review: An excellent throwback title to the time when video games were video games, Crypt Stalker looks and feels like an NES game, complete with slowdowns and flickering for complete immersion. However, both features can be turned off from the menu if needed. The game offers tight platforming with fun, well-designed stages and boss fights. It can be frustratingly challenging at times, but never unfair. It's also worth mentioning that the purchase includes a shorter Game Boy demake, which is an absolute blast to play through. I can easily recommend this to any child of the 80s who has fond memories of beating a difficult game, with sweaty hands still gripping the controller while the credits roll. I can't wait to see what Sinclair Strange is up to next. Well done, guys!

author: {'steamid': '76561198170691582', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 113, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 113, 'last_played': 1615068943}
review:
Counter to the other reviews, I don’t think Crypt Stalker is fun or wroth your time. The ideas behind the game are solid, however, the execution largely fails.

Pros:

Your character’s attacks are implemented well. I really like the combination of the upgradable whip and gun sub-weapon with various ammo types. 

Apart from the primary game, there are a variety of distinct modes and challenges. 

Cons:

Level design is built around trial and error. While this might appeal to some, I find it to be antiquated and truly unenjoyable as it forces the player to continually repeat purposefully frustrating sections of the game. 

The movement is horrendous. On foot, the character moves too fast for the environment. Conversely, for some odd reason, your jump attack slows you down midair and shortens your jump distance. The contrast during gameplay is maddening. Additionally, inputs can be lost. For example, if you're moving forward and want to attack in the opposite direction, you'll need to stop, turn and then attack. Otherwise, the input will be lost.  

The visual design is largely unappealing. The backgrounds are largely uninteresting and muddy while the characters are garish. Again, it’s an odd contrast.

review: A lot of retro indie games fall into the trap of being too beholden to what they're emulatingto really break out. CRYPT STALKERS is *not* one of those games. It is very clearly inspired by Castlevania, but it adds to and plays with the formula in enough ways that it stands on its own. The major way it sets itself apart is the proliferation of platforming puzzles: each stage introduces some new mechanic (blocks that raise when you stand on them; lights that go out unless you hit a switch; lava that periodically raises to engulf the lower half of the screen; and so on) and explores it to a degree that Castlevania never did. Certainly I would recommend this to any fan of the classic Castlevanias; but I'd also recommend it to anyone who enjoys challenging and inventive platformers, regardless of how they feel about that series.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991130847', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 102, 'playtime_forever': 153, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 153, 'last_played': 1609171347}
review:
Si vous êtes amateurs de la série des Castlevania (époque NES), des gros pixels colorés et des fouets, alors Crypt Stalker est certainement fait pour vous.

Dans la peau d'une tueuse de démons lambda, vous allez devoir parcourir une demi-douzaine de niveaux dans la plus pure tradition du genre, à grand renfort de plates-formes, de luminaires contenant des tas de trucs, de monstres aux patterns définis et de boss plus ou moins coriaces. Tout comme dans son illustre modèle, votre arme principale est un fouet, pouvant rapidement être amélioré avec le bon objet, et vous possédez également un pistolet aux munitions limitées pouvant prendre plusieurs formes (shotgun, laser, déflagration...). Rajoutez des cuisses de poulet cachées dans les murs, une musique 8-bit entraînante, un scrolling qui ne vous permet pas de revenir en arrière, et les habitués ne seront pas dépaysés ! Seule la maniabilité est un peu différente, étant beaucoup moins rigide, et le personnage étant plus rapide. Le jeu est aussi assez facile, notamment grâce au système de sauvegarde entre chaque niveau.

En plus de l'aventure principale, on notera également une version typée gameboy avec moins de niveaux mais tout aussi complète, et la présence d'une quinzaine de niveaux challenge (finir avec un nombre limité de sauts, sans pouvoir attaquer...) ainsi que d'un boss rush ; des ajouts qui font plaisir et augmentent un peu la durée de vie (pas plus de 3h au total).

Bref, en période de soldes et entre 1 et 2 euros, le jeu vaut bien le détour, si toutefois vous êtes réceptifs au genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198243559964', 'num_games_owned': 219, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 140, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 135, 'last_played': 1611930182}
review:
参考FC恶魔城和NATSUME游戏的类恶魔城作品，玩法上与恶魔城基本一致，同时取消副武器变为手枪，同时手枪可以自由切换并且有四种子弹效果，不过都需要消耗子弹才可发射，此外游戏过程中还有一种钩子可以利用鞭子进行摆动（类似SFC超级恶魔城），其他就是经典恶魔城玩法了，一共9关可供挑战。
游戏最大的问题是移动中突然停下会有一种惯性，同时跳跃的感觉很糟糕，受伤后的弹飞距离也相对较多，主角移动速度过快导致游戏过程中基本都是被自己操作坑死的，当然游戏中最致命的还是主武器鞭子距离太短了，只有前方向两格距离。
其他的如画面和音乐均没有令人耳目一新的亮点，如果是传统恶魔城爱好者可以尝试但并不推荐，同时画面过糊，有些敌人掺在背景里糊到一起还挺有迷彩效果，坑你没商量。
游戏还有EXTRA挑战模式（内含六种挑战，可解锁成就），GB风游戏模式（共4关），不过个人觉得GB模式要比传统模式手感好得多。

review: The developer's skills have improved greatly since his last games, from what I know about them! Basically, if you're considering this game try Bloodstained: Curse of the Moon unless you're on a budget, and if you already have that game this is where you should go next instead of Curse of the Moon 2. There are some important differences here from Castlevania (and Curse of the Moon): for one thing, you can turn in midair, and for another, there seems to be some sense of momentum. The levels also each have their own gimmick, and the challenges are a nice extra bit for people who are really good at the game. Also unlike Curse of the Moon, you can hook on to things with your whip (though you can only use it straight ahead). The subweapons also resemble those of Contra more than Castlevania, though there are differences even with that series. There are still quite a few bugs, but those aside the visuals and music are on Curse of the Moon levels, if not better! It's also good there's a sound test.

Supongo que el jefe final me dejo entre medio decepcionado y no (Spoiler hasta que termine el parentesis, la 1ra fase es extremadamente fácil de ganar, la 2da te da una batalla digna, la 3ra es una boludez, salvo que no tengas balas, pero antes de la batalla reponés munición)

-Historia: Está en ingles y mucho no entendí... pero es tan sencilla que te das una idea fácilmente y... supongo que termina siendo una trama demasiado simplona

Después pasando a errores, bugs o cosas que no me gustaron tanto

-No termino de entender el sistema de Upgrade del látigo, a veces agarro un item que me lo pone al tope... o no, porque tampoco comprendí cuando estaba en su máximo poder y... medio raro

author: {'steamid': '76561197988422543', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 163, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 121, 'last_played': 1684903991}
review:
With Crypt Stalker, Sinclair Strange takes us back to the glory days of the NES.  You take the role of an Indiana Jones-esque Crypt Stalker, at first finding yourself fighting temple guards and scarabs.  As you venture deeper, the experience turns more demonic and the enemies more otherworldly.  Armed with a taser whip and sidearm you traverse nine levels of water, lava, space, and other environments as you struggle to end the curse and save the world. 

Some clever level mechanics make their appearance, such as shifting floors controlled by standing on "up" and "down" arrow blocks, but most of the platforming experience you'll find in Crypt Stalker stays true to the traditional formula.  You can expect spikes, pitfalls, conveyor belts, and other familiar challenges as you make your way to battle demons.   

The game is ripe with classic Castlevania inspiration.  Your whip is upgradeable.  The bosses drop orbs when slain.  You gain ammunition, money, and other items by breaking objects suspended overhead.  The level select system, which provides a permanent save when you finish a level, offers some relief of the harsh punishment of old Castlevania games, but doesn't detract from the experience. 

There is definite love for the 8-bit era here.  Everything is as you would expect after blowing off an NES cartridge, sticking it in your deck, and pushing the power button on.  Strange has taken into account every detail of the NES experience, from momentarily disappearing sprites to hue changes as the level backgrounds appear from the right side of the screen in a side scrolling level, it's all there.  Add to this the ability to play a handheld gameboy version of the game (which offers all new levels and challenges) and you'll find yourself knee deep in 90's gaming nostalgia.

Overall, I was greatly pleased with the game.  The amount of content here is generous for the low price tag.  The combat can be frustrating with the classic "knockback" into a pit, but it's not beyond expectation.  The only detraction is a frustrating bug that keeps you stuck in the floor when using one of the rising floors.  Other than that, the experience inside of Crypt Stalker is a flawless 8-bit experience which brings back all the joys and tension of NES gaming.  

8/10, 9/10 if the bug gets fixed.

I'm in my 30's, first ever console I owned was an NES I bought new at Toys 'R' Us with birthday money.   There was so much excitement, spent the whole drive home looking at the box with all the wonderful art on it of Duck Hunt and Mario Bro's.  I haven't really felt that kind of excitement since those days.  Then today I see this game, I bought it and downloaded it and I'm reliving my childhood.  For the first time in ages, I feel excited over a game like I used to.

From the 8bit track to the typical NES graphics, this game has it all.  It's no cake walk, just like any old school game.  But it's fun and filled with "Nestalgia" as the devs put it.  

I'm loving it, and if you like any kind of retro gaming you will too.  And you can't beat the price!  I'd gladly have paid 10x as much!

review:
Castlevania I for the NES is one of my favorite games of all time. I wanted to play a game that captured a similar feeling to it, so I tried Bloodstained: Curse of the Moon. That game is boring as fuck and it got old quick.

Now, this game. This game is a masterpiece. It's fast paced old school Castlevania action to the point where I wouldn't even say it's Castlevania and it is just its own thing.

The level design is unbelievably creative and clever. Each level has a distinct theme and pushes its limits, eventually having you play through a hell gauntlet of every level in a single grueling stage. The bosses are awesome. Extremely creative and challenging. 

The art is using the NES style at its best and the music is not slacking either.

This is already one of my favorite games of all time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071753285', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 86, 'playtime_forever': 203, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11, 'last_played': 1676613177}
review:
So many faux retro games don't nail the feel of the era. They're just modern games with pixel art, slamming "RETRO GAME" in their marketing to sell. Crypt Stalker, like A Whole New World, Lament or (to a lesser extent) Inti's Bloodstained games, actually nail the feel of a game designed in those days. Crypt Stalker scales automatically to my CRT which is a beautiful feature (A Whole New World does too). 

Another thing Crypt Stalker offers is the GameBoy mode which I love. If you look at GameBoy ports of NES games tons of them are somewhat enhanced, offering more features and or different level designs (Kung Fu Master springs to mind). Crypt Stalker's GameBoy mode feels like one of those GameBoy ports, offering different level design and mechanics while keeping the same general gameplay and premise. This mode is something I absolutely love after my years of emulating and exploring different console ports and games on my XP machine as a kid. Scratches a super niche itch. 

Crypt Stalker feels like one of those unheard of games you'd randomly try from a ROM site from back in the day only to enjoy it, find out theres a GameBoy port and try that too, finding a hidden gem. Games like this and the ones mentioned above nail the feel of the obscure NES game unlike so many "LOOK AT ME IM RETRO" games. Plus the gameplays just super fun, give it a go.

author: {'steamid': '76561198431334459', 'num_games_owned': 369, 'num_reviews': 102, 'playtime_forever': 283, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 105, 'last_played': 1604883908}
review:
Bom clone dos Castlevanias do NES. Os gráficos 8-bit são mais pixelados do que no próprio NES, porém crocantes. As músicas e efeitos sonoros são ok, sem grandes destaques. A jogabilidade é boa, mas em alguns momentos a física é estranha. A tela não rola de volta depois que vc avança, gerando problemas com plataformas móveis e telas de subida vertical. O fator replay é bacana, devido à boa dificuldade, ao charmoso "modo Gameboy", aos challenges (desafios) bem pensados e ao modo boss rush.

Não espere algo no nível de Bloodstained: Curse of the Moon, mas o jogo é bom e barato. Vale preço cheio. Recomendo aos amantes de Castlevania 1 e 3 do NES!

I totally recommend it, the quality is on par with Bloodstained Curse of the Moon. The protagonist looks like if Blaze from Streets of Rage had a baby with Lina inverse, and Indiana Jones was the baby shower's host.

10/10

(This game should be priced $9.99, in my opinion)

review:
Good game, especially at this price point (grab it before the launch sale expires if you can).
It gave me more of a Vice: Project Doom vibe rather than the Classicvania one it was going for, especially due to its way faster pace when compared to CV, but that's not a bad thing at all.
I've managed to 100% it in the span of 3 hours, including the challenges and the boss rush, but less seasoned players might take quite a bit more time, given the increase in difficulty of the latter levels.
My only real gripes have to do with some bugs, such as getting stuck in the arrow-guided elevator in both of the levels it showed up in and jumping over the screen ceiling in another level (I think it was a section in level 6).
Also the No Whip and Pacifist achievement were swapped, as in I unlocked one of them by doing the other one and vice versa, so you might want to look into this too.
All in all, given its cheap price and VERY good value, if you're on the fence, just go for it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198010992095', 'num_games_owned': 4542, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 69, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 23, 'last_played': 1641899395}
review:
So, being a HUGE fan of Metroidvania's (I've kickstarted a few at this point and thank goodness, they were successful projects) I must say...first impressions? Awesome. Sinclair Strange (the Dev/Publisher) is pretty spot on. I'd even go so far as to say it's around the same quality as Blood Stained: Curse of the Moon (the 2D Spin-Off of Ritual of the Night). 

Graphics? As GOOD as 8-Bit can get. Well drawn sprites. SMOOTH AS SILK animation frames. I love the music (though it's not entirely Egyptian sounding, it still sounds like something you'd hear back in the day from a game by Jaleco or one of the other 3rd party devs back in the day). Gameplay and controls are SOLID! 5/5 GET THIS.

Bonus: I forgot the mention that the game comes with a free smaller-game that you can complete from start to finish, disguised as the game's "Game Boy Mode". It's a separate game that looks like a Game Boy port, but it's like comparing Operation C on GB to Contra/Super-C on NES. Different levels, designs, graphics, etc.

I thought to mention, the Dev has also made a couple other games (Alien Splatter, Fist Slash, and Jet Gunner) which are fun. Alien Splatter reminds me of "Vice : Project Doom" for the NES.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040295426', 'num_games_owned': 625, 'num_reviews': 130, 'playtime_forever': 27, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 27, 'last_played': 1604275368}
review:
The price tag gave me a lot to think about. Clearly a lot of effort went into the game making me think  the dev might be underselling him/herself, but it's also far from perfect, so a lot of criticisms I, or anyone else, might have that would result in a non recommendation for a $20 game sorts itself out here.

It's a neat and short game though, I liked it. My main criticism would be the two difficulty levels: retro difficult and casual. These are so opposite to each other in the difficulty spectrum. Do you prefer being tickled or being waterboarded? I played a few levels on the retro level and couldn't stomach it. It also had a few bugs because it was just released. But today I tried the casual mode and, as expected, it was trivially easy. You just move forward and mash attack until credits roll down.

This criticism comes with appreciation for including a casual mode though! it could very easily just be one super hard difficulty and that's it. At least there's an option for me to stroll through the game if I don't want to rage quit a million times.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972431488', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 230, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 147, 'last_played': 1604187874}
review:
This was a pleasant surprise. It's a fun and short nes styled game that has some elements of Castlevania, Ninja Gaiden and Vice: Project Doom tossed in with a solid OST. The level design was solid for the most part with only a few screens that felt tedious. The bosses where also well done even though it felt like some where lifted from some other indie games especially the water monster boss in stage 3. My only real complaints are with the jumping and there was a few things that bothered me over it. 

1. Losing your jump distance when whipping an enemy is some bad design especially when you have to do this over pits.
2. There is some level sections that require you to short jump. To trigger short jump which I had to flick the button to activate it can be a pain since these parts usually led to death or a lot of damage done if you did the normal jump instead.
3. The jump arc is rather large and when coupled with having to shorten it to navigate obstacles and land on a moving platform it can be annoying.

Otherwise for 3 bucks this is a steal of a game if you like retro gaming.

review:
Incredible game, and incredible value. 
If you enjoy great 8-bit adventures namely Castlevania then hit that buy button now. The game features an NES console and Gameboy variant versions, and the Gameboy version isn't merely a palette swap either. If this were £10.00 it would still be great value, but with a launch price of £1.40 it's an insane deal. The one slight downside is  that the whip feels a little too short at times, but that is honestly a minor niggle. I fell in love with this developers previous game 'Jet Gunner' from the moment i fired it up. It's been an exhaustive wait to finally get a new game from his talented hands, and i hope people support it and let him know we definitely want more. All i can say is buy it!

review:
I don't always go for these types of games because of the been there done that feel of them. I was alive during this time so I am all Nintendo'd out. But this game had something that just caught my eye. And ear. I really like the music. That is the main thing that got the nostalgia going. The price is really low so it's not a huge risk anyway so I went ahead and gave it a shot. It is pretty much what I expected. A fun lite Castlevania style game.

There are 2 versions  to play through. Console and Handheld. There is also a challenge mode in with different stages where you must complete a small level with various handicaps.

The developer has already fixed the two problems I had with the game. Easy recommendation. This indie developer has done what huge corporations can't even do. Read the forums. Saw the issues. Fixed the issues.

author: {'steamid': '76561198255256194', 'num_games_owned': 382, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 23, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 23, 'last_played': 1604109340}
review:
It's okay, but honestly, you should just play Bloodstained: Curse of the Moon instead.

The controls and animations feel off, certain enemies have an absurd amount of health, and it just doesn't quite replicate that deliberate, tactical feel that made Castlevania great (you move way too fast and can control your mid-air momentum, yet your main attack is painfully slow and there's still knockback. It's got some of the ingredients, but not all of them). Also, it claims to have a save system, but it appears to either be broken or not explained properly (I couldn't figure out how to resume from the second stage after beating the first one, none of the buttons let me pick a stage).

Solid 5/10 (as in "average" not "F-"). Not bad (especially for a solo dev), but definitely not great. Giving it a thumbs up because the world needs more classic Castlevania (and there are two campaigns, one of which is a throwback to the Gameboy CVs, which is cool).
